intro: Zootrophion hypodiscus, commonly known as the African moonflower, is a climbing plant native to southern Africa. It is characterized by its large, showy white flowers that open at night, attracting nocturnal pollinators such as moths. The plant has a woody stem with a rough, ridged texture and produces small, round fruits that contain numerous seeds. Its leaves are simple, alternate, and have a slightly hairy surface. Zootrophion hypodiscus thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often growing in shaded or semi-shaded areas.
